title: 108_s911
content: The "Wage Tax Cut Act of 2003" allows for the refund of employee payroll taxes. The "Wage Tax Cut Act of 2003" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to refund individuals an amount equal to the lesser of $765 or their social security taxes for 2001 in two installments, with the first payment two months after enactment and the second on December 1, 2003. Adjustments in payment timing can be made with notice to Congress. No interest shall be allowed on any payment required by this subsection. Certain individuals not eligible for payment include estates, trusts, nonresident aliens, and individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code for a taxable year beginning in 2001. Social security taxes are defined as per section 24(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines social security taxes for individuals not covered by the social security system. In 2002, a refund is provided for individuals who did not receive a full refund in 2001. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section in Subchapter B of chapter 65, related to abatements, credits, and refunds. "SEC. 6429. REFUND OF CERTAIN 2002 PAYROLL TAXES." The text discusses the refund of certain 2002 payroll taxes for eligible individuals. The refund amount is calculated based on the individual's social security taxes for 2002 and the payment received under the Wage Tax Cut Act of 2003. Eligible individuals exclude estates, trusts, nonresident aliens, and individuals with specific deductions. The text discusses the refund of 2002 payroll taxes for eligible individuals, excluding certain entities. The Secretary will refund or credit overpayments promptly, with no interest, before December 31, 2003. Social security taxes are defined as per the Wage Tax Cut Act of 2003. SEC. 6430 allows for a refund of employer payroll taxes on the first $10,000 of wages per employee. During the payroll tax holiday period, employers subject to tax under section 3111 or 3221(a) are treated as having made a payment against the tax imposed by chapter 1 for each taxable year. The payroll tax refund amount for an employee is the excess of $765 or the employer's social security taxes paid with respect to the employee during the holiday period within the taxable year. During the payroll tax holiday period, employers are considered to have made a payment against the tax imposed by chapter 1 for each taxable year. The payroll tax refund amount for an employee is the excess of $765 or the employer's social security taxes paid with respect to the employee during the holiday period within the taxable year. The term 'payroll tax holiday period' refers to the 12-month period starting from the month following the enactment of this section, with the option for the Secretary to delay the start if necessary. Employer payroll taxes include taxes imposed by sections 3111 and 3221(a). The term 'employment' includes services subject to tax under chapter 22. Special rules apply for common control and the trade or business requirement for employer payroll taxes. The remuneration for services performed in a trade or business of the employer is determined without regard to specific sections of the tax code. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. "Sec. 6430 allows for a refund of employer payroll taxes on the first $10,000 of an employee's wages."
